tasks.task: Understand garden characteristics and prepare soil
subtasks: Observe sunlight exposure
Note shade and direct sunlight areas
Conduct soil test to determine pH and nutrient content
Loosen soil with garden fork or tiller
Remove weeds, rocks, and debris
Amend soil with organic matter (compost, aged manure)
Consider climate zone, space, and personal preferences
Select native species
Mix plant species with different colors, textures, and heights
Follow spacing recommendations
Dig holes larger than root balls
Gently loosen roots before planting
Water thoroughly after planting
Provide deep, infrequent watering
Water early morning to minimize evaporation
Avoid wetting foliage
Use balanced fertilizer (equal N-P-K)
Follow manufacturer instructions
Choose organic mulch (leaves, straw, wood chips)
Apply 2-3 inches depth
Leave space around stems
Encourage natural predators (ladybugs, lacewings, birds)
Monitor plants for pests/disease
Remove affected plant material promptly
Prune dead/diseased branches
Remove spent flowers
Regularly check for weeds and remove
for each major task, then SUBTASK: for each subtask under that.
Observe sunlight exposure
Note shade and direct sunlight areas
Conduct soil test to determine pH level and nutrient content
Consider climate zone, available space, and personal preferences
Select native species
Choose a variety of plants with different colors, textures, and heights
Loosen soil with a garden fork or tiller
Remove weeds, rocks, and debris
Amend soil with organic matter such as compost or aged manure
Follow spacing recommendations provided on seed packets or plant tags
Dig holes slightly larger than the root balls of the plants
Gently loosen the roots before planting
Water thoroughly after planting to settle the soil and reduce transplant shock
Provide deep, infrequent watering
Water early in the morning to minimize evaporation
Avoid wetting the foliage
Choose a balanced fertilizer with equal parts nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium
Apply fertilizer according to the manufacturer's instructions
Apply a layer of organic mulch (e.g., shredded leaves, straw, wood chips)
Leave a few inches of space around the stems
Encourage natural predators such as ladybugs, lacewings, and birds
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests or diseases
Promptly remove and dispose of affected plant material
Prune dead or diseased branches
Remove spent flowers to encourage continued blooming
Regularly check for weeds and remove them
